dt: {bc}to treat as nonexistent {bc}to fail to do what is required by (something, such as a responsibility)

dt.t: The company's directors are accused of {it}abrogating{/it} their responsibilities.

dt: {bc}to suppress or prevent (a biological function or process and especially an immune response)

dt.t: Continued progress in measurement and characterization of antibodies and strategies to {wi}abrogate{/wi} antibody production both prior to and following heart transplant have been encouraging.

pt: {sc}nullify{/sc} {sc}negate{/sc} {sc}annul{/sc} {sc}abrogate{/sc} {sc}invalidate{/sc} mean to deprive of effective or continued existence. {sc}nullify{/sc} implies counteracting completely the force, effectiveness, or value of something.
{sc}negate{/sc} implies the destruction or canceling out of each of two things by the other.
{sc}annul{/sc} suggests making ineffective or nonexistent often by legal or official action.
{sc}abrogate{/sc} is like {sc}annul{/sc} but more definitely implies a legal or official act.
{sc}invalidate{/sc} implies making something powerless or unacceptable by declaration of its logical or moral or legal unsoundness.

quotes.t: For their part, some of the pipeline companies saddled with these contracts for high-priced, deregulated gas have declared that they will simply {qword}abrogate{/qword} them …
We may not always like what we hear but we are always the poorer if we close down dialogue; if we {qword}abrogate{/qword} free speech, and the open exchange of ideas.
If UAL continues to bleed red ink, some analysts say bankruptcy—which would allow it to {qword}abrogate{/qword} its union contracts—may be its only hope.

et: borrowed from Latin {it}abrogātus{/it}, past participle of {it}abrogāre{/it}, "to repeal (a law), repudiate, cancel," from {it}ab-{/it} {et_link|ab-|ab-} + {it}rogāre{/it} "to ask, ask an assembly for approval of" {ma}{mat|rogation|}{/ma}
shortdef: to abolish by authoritative action : annul
to treat as nonexistent : to fail to do what is required by (something, such as a responsibility)
to suppress or prevent (a biological function or process and especially an immune response)
